awd_titl_txt: Financing Strategies and Reducing Carbon Emissions from Cookstoves
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will examine the impacts of new forms of financing on the adoption and use of new cookstove technologies designed to reduce toxic and environmentally harmful emissions and improve the health of household members using the stoves.  Efforts to spur the replacement of traditional, high pollution-emitting stoves with cleaner, more modern devices have been supported by a number of international programs, with efforts led by the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves, which was created by the United Nations.  This research project will investigate whether carbon financing is aiding or hindering the delivery of cooking technologies, their compatibility with household preferences, and their effectiveness at reducing indoor air pollution.  The project will improve understanding of carbon market impacts on household-scale development as well as how carbon mitigation programs produce benefits and burdens that often accumulate in geographically and socially uneven ways.  The project will advance scholarship in development geography by contributing to debates assessing the development impacts of carbon markets and by pinpointing the roles played by a diverse set of actors within complex carbon-based development projects.  Project findings will help increase the health and development benefits of low carbon technology interventions and provide new perspectives on ways in which rural sustainable development activities can complement new strategies for livelihoods that rely on less carbon.

With nearly one-half of the world's population using rudimentary cookstoves, the likelihood of toxic emissions leading to severe health problems is extremely high.  Traditional cookstoves also emit large amounts of greenhouse gases, thereby contributing to atmospheric pollution and increasing the carbon footprint in many parts of the world.  This project will focus on three core questions:  (1) How does carbon financing influence the distribution of stoves with respect to stove affordability, household suitability and emissions performance?  (2) How can supply chains using carbon finance be modified to improve results along each of those factors?  (3) How do households influence development outcomes along the supply chain? The investigators will conduct household and production chain surveys as well as management agency interviews in two cookstove project regions in India to gain insights into decisions made for allocating flows of carbon finance to cookstove projects and strategies for improving the integration of carbon markets.  They will statistically analyze data to determine the relationships among responses, subject attributes, and other conditions.  Preexisting stove emissions data for all stoves will be analyzed to determine household air pollution levels for all pre- and post-carbon finance stove models.  Project findings will shed light on the effectiveness of programs supported by the U.S. that encourage the adoption of energy-efficient affordable stoves that release fewer pollutants, improve human health, reduce environmental degradation, and foster economic growth.

por.por_cntn:
Throughout India and around the developing world a large number of projects are facilitating the replacement of traditional, high-polluting household cookstoves with newer, cleaner and more efficient cooking devices. These “clean cookstove projects” are popular with private investors, governments and non-profit groups because newer stoves can reduce harmful greenhouse gas emissions that contribute to climate change, improve indoor air quality for stove users, and also increase social and ecological vitality in areas receiving new stoves. This research project assessed two clean cookstove projects, one in the State of Karnataka and the other in the State of Andhra Pradesh. The project investigated many of the benefits touted by the clean cookstove sector by comparing project policy objectives with experienced outcomes at the household scale. 

 

More specifically, this project sought to (a) understand factors that influence the adoption and sustained use of clean cookstoves in each study area and (b) provide a more nuanced understanding of the benefits derived from the acquisition of clean cookstoves, particularly related to women’s daily routines and fuelwood collection activities. This project deployed a range of research methods including a 170-question household survey (over 1200 surveys), focus group interviews (12 extended sessions), participant observation, drawings (from 25 participating groups) and global positioning system (GPS) tracking technologies.

 

While our research revealed many valuable insights, a few findings stand out:

 

(1) Clean cookstoves do reduce smoke in the cooking area in significant ways, although the amount of emissions reductions often does not meet expected decreases because of the complex and household-specific way stoves and fuel types are used. We found that more or larger burners which can accommodate larger families may improve stove compatibility and may prevent households from using additional and/or traditional stoves during family events, festivals, etc.

 

(2) Many critics believe that stove users will be unable or unwilling to adapt their ritual practices to new, improved stoves. To the contrary, we found that, for most households in our study, applying most cultural and spiritual practices to improved cookstoves is not a major barrier to stove uptake. 

 

(3) While women do save some time when using their new cookstoves, the total time savings are often small and fragmented and do not easily accommodate market participation, and thereby limit forms of ‘economic empowerment’. This undercuts one of the core arguments in favor of clean cookstove interventions.  However, these time saving can still change and improve women’s daily routines by allowing for multitasking while cooking and generating free time for women to spend with friends, family, etc. 

 

(4) Because improved stoves can burn smaller pieces of wood, they can lead to a reduction in the distance women must walk to collect fuel. The time saved collecting fuel allows women to collect other forest items, improving their livelihoods and perhaps their income. Furthermore, although fuelwood collection for cooking is often blamed for local rates deforestation, there is little evidence from our research that wood is collected through unsustainably harvested sources. It therefore does not appear that decreasing the amount of fuel used for cooking will necessarily ‘protect’ nearby forests, as is commonly articulated within the clean cookstove sector. 

 

(5) Cookstove projects may help households become exposed to other types of locally run projects that increase household resilience to climate change, such as sustainable agriculture and health services. Thus, while cookstove projects function as climate change mitigation projects by reducing carbon emissions, they also operate as useful mechanisms to increase climate change adaptation by introducing communities to resources that boost community health and well-being. It is therefore advisable that organizations managing clean cookstove projects also deliver other social welfare programs. 

 

Our findings suggest that the positive and negative impacts of clean cookstoves are difficult to assess and are best understood in a case by case and location by location manner. Many of the assumptions embedded in clean cookstove projects are simply not accurate and may simplify the experiences and capacities of locally participating organizations, households and individual stove users. More targeted, project-specific analysis is therefore advised to understand the impact of clean cookstove projects. 

 

Detailed project findings (introduced above) have been shared with local organizations through high quality project summary reports. We hope these public-facing documents will meaningfully improve their future engagements with clean cookstove projects and lead to more sustainable and equitable outcomes for participating households. Furthermore, insights from this study have been published in various academic journals in order to improve our understanding of the relationship between technology-driven development projects and the daily lives of targeted households.
